author: dwdsquared2
body:
**Events in the US Today (EDT):**

* 8:55am - Redbook (YoY&MoM) \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 9:00am - S&P/CS HPI Composite Data \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 10:00am - CB Consumer Confidence (Jul) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Richmond Manuf. & Services Index, Shipments (Jul) \[1/3 Volatility\]
   * The Senate convenes for session
* 10:30am - Dallas Fed Services Revenue (Jul) \[1/3 Volatility\]
   * Texas Services Sector Outlook (Jul) \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 4:30pm - API Weekly Crude Oil Stock \[2/3 Volatility\]
* Investors are betting setbacks in the fight against the coronavirus will lead Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell to signal Wednesday that rates will stay near zero for longer
   * The Federal Open Market Committee holds its policy meeting **today**, with an **a****nnouncement due on Wednesday**
* Senate Republicans presented a $1 trillion proposal as a first step toward negotiating a compromise with Democrats, who’ve offered their own $3.5 trillion plan
   * Headlining the proposal is a reduction of the enhanced unemployment insurance from $600 to $200 per week
   * The HEALS Act will also include another round of direct checks to some Americans that will mirror those that were distributed after the CARES Act was approved in late March. The proposal would give a one-time check to those making up to $75,000 a year, with the amount winding down before it hits the $99,000 income ceiling
   * It also includes $1.75 billion for construction of new FBI building
*  U.S. second-quarter GDP is expected on Thursday

**Events in the World Today (EDT):**

* 8:30am - Brazil Current Account (USD-Jun) \[1/3 Volatility\]
* 2:00pm - Brazil CAGED Net Payroll Jobs \[2/3 Volatility\]
* 9:30pm - Australia CPI (QoQ-Q2) \[3/3 Volatility\]
   * Australia Trimmed Mean CIP (QoQ-Q2) \[2/3 Volatility\]
* The ECB extended its recommendation that banks pay no dividends by another six months to the end of the year

**Earnings Before Open:**

* Pfizer, McDonald's, 3M, Raytheon Technologies, Centene Corp., Altria, jetBlue, Harley Davidson, Sherwin Williams, LabCorp

**Earnings After Close:**

* AMD, Visa, eBay, Starbucks, Dexcom, FireEye, Akamai, Amgen, Oneok, Avis Budget Group

[Earnings This Week](https://i.redd.it/6i19e9do82d51.jpg)

author: bumblebear3012
body:
Neither of these names are speculative. In fact, I believe both companies - should they continue to position themselves accordingly - have one of the longest growth runways of any stocks on the market. I realize that is quite the statement, but most of the analysts and commentators have not had a full understanding of the technologies on offer or the potential end-markets these two can service (I suppose you can throw Akamai into the mix, but they’ve been slower to get into the edge computing game). 

A lot of people have almost exclusively characterized these two as CDN providers. A content delivery network utilizes edge servers (servers placed at a geographical proximity closer to the end-user) to cache web content (text, images, videos, etc.) from websites and applications so that they can be sent to a web client more quickly and more securely. 

However, that is just one part of what these companies offer. The real promise for me is 5G and IoT. As the 5G buildout matures, it will be more economical to deploy IoT devices for a greater breadth of companies. Because of this, there will be an exponential demand for data transmission. Projections have put the growth of the global datasphere at nearly 300% over the next four years alone. 

Security will be huge in this type of computing environment, more so than today even, as sensors and IoT devices track and manage the performance of logistics, industrial, and transportation systems. Despite numerous advantages of edge computing, it also increases the number of attack vectors for network intrusion. Therefore security offerings and DDoS mitigation capacity will be big selling points for IoT customers to choose a network provider. 

While the CDN market will continue to grow at a fairly consistent pace as more people work from home, stream video, do shopping online, etc., the broader edge computing market will probably end up dwarfing the CDN market in terms of size. 

For me, you can definitely say the valuations are stretched - on pretty much any metric. At the same time, I don’t think the TAM that these companies are exposed to is being fully taken into account. Neither is the fact that this is a mega-trend that will likely not run its full course until 2030 or 2035. 

Risks are that they lose competitive positioning, end-market demands shift, too much spending on the network prevents profitability and multiples eventually shrink as growth comes down. I’m sure new ones could emerge, but it’s not hard for me to see how these companies can continue to execute and sustain richer valuations. Especially in the case of Cloudflare, with their margins, they have the potential to be a cash cow.

author: notbrokemexican
body:
I have heavy DD in my profile on this subject.

In a nutshell; cloudflare is cybersec and IT cloud. Fastly is media optimization (aka video gold mine).

The CDN industry is not a zero sum game. cloudflare is more of a competitor to Akamai. Limelight Networks is more of a competitor to Fastly.


They share a lot of the same mechanics but the differentiator is their product focus. High quality speed only makes privacy less of a business risk and they don't charge you more for getting DDoSed. 

Fastly will give you cheap and quality video services.

Neither lock you into a vendor like Azure or AWS.

author: PM_Me_Ur_Greyhound
body:
Three plays. Various timelines.

Immediate: Akamai Technologies (AKAM). Cyber infrastructure play. Meh company but trading at a significant discount to its peers. Earnings Tuesday.

Medium: SuRo Capital (SSS). Large investment in Palantir and two e-education start ups that are about to IPO. NAV is around $12/share, right now trading in the mid $13s.

Long: VanEck Vectors Vietnam (VNM). Already did a rant about why I think this will be good. Dong is stabilizing, economy growing, zero covid deaths. Just need Vingroup CEO not to die in the next 5 years.

author: ejobit
body:
>AKAM

Just looked at AKAM charts - was $300+ in 99 then under $1 in 2002.

author: knowledgemule
body:
i think when it was first ipo'd it was in a weird no man's land of healthcare and tech and now the multiple clearly endorses the tech view. I met w/ them at a conference and it all makes sense to me. clearly costs too high - this is a very cheap total cost ownership thing that is sold to who actually cares about the costs being too high, your employer lol. The healthcare system wants them higher forever. Do some light searches in the diabetes forums about LVGO - will be helpful too. If they become a defacto standard it really gets going. All in all seems like an "obviously" good idea. 

Meanwhile CDNs lol. i have done a lot work and it's clear they have some special execution going on at FSLY, but AKAM invented this category and has only ceded share

author: gzaw1
body:
As a website owner cloudflare is the premier/leading CDN for individual website owners.  

If you’re enterprise, you’re more likely to use someone like fastly or akamai.

author: ZeroBullshitMan
body:
I like cloudflare a lot. I moved my DNS / CDN management off Azure and to them. They let you manage domains, conduct filtering and redirect HTTPS traffic. All for free!

It's a great way to get new customers. If I need one of the paid services they provide, it's much simpler to keep all my shit on Cloudflare.

But they've been around a while and have a lot of competitors.

You should look up Akamai, I think almost all Facebook content is hosted via them. But I haven't been on Facebook in about 12 years.

Also Fastly is a bit of s growth stock. Can't be 100% they won't fall over, but they're much younger.

author: bumblebear3012
body:
Adobe, Akamai, Square, Doordash are among the clients and there are some pretty talented developers and data scientists at those companies. 

Plus AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud aren’t synced with Salesforce data. Companies are increasingly looking to avoid over-reliance on a single cloud vendor. 

Those factors, combined with the extremely flexible pricing, provide enough of a need for their 2000 enterprise customers by the looks of it.

body:

So many articles have been written on Fastly lately. The company has recently IPOd and had a tremendous growth in a very short period of time. Inevitably the question about sustainability is raised. 
Tons of analyst are saying that Akamai should benefit greatly from 5G development. Is it capable to outperform Fastly and Cloudflare?

author: herk_destro
body: AWS provides Edge as a service, like Akamai. Netflix is just a long time customer.  Also by comingling their stuff with AWS it becomes harder for ISPs to discriminate against thier service without being obvious.

author: SS324
body:
Cloudflare also hosts stormfront and their CEO is insane.  Consider the political climate.  If you invest in Cloudflare you may want to hedge in Akamai, netscout, or fastly.

TBH, just buy shares in all of them.  This is growing market.

author: thekidtheycountedout
body:
Hi! 18 year old recent high school graduate here. I’m looking to invest a lot of my savings before college. I have no debts, about $15,000 to invest , and make about $400 per week. All I want is for my money to make money for me. My timespan is 30+ years. This is all money I’m prepared to put aside for a while. I’ve been doing a lot of reading the past few weeks and have come up with a few companies I’d like to invest in. Feedback on my ideas (good idea/bad idea/etc.) and any advice in general is much appreciated. I haven’t looked into anything but single companies thus far, and want to look into other ways to invest but don’t know where to start, so recommendations on where to start would great. 

My ideas thus far:
Verizon, 
Clorox,
General dynamics,
Nvidia ,
Square ,
Akamai ,
Scott’s Miracle Gro ,
Advanced Micro Devices ,
Thermo Fisher Scientific ,
Lockheed Martin ,
Northrop Grumman 

I know these are all massive companies and represent value rather than growth investing. I do want to invest in some growth shares, but have no idea where to start. Tech, energy, and defense are my preferred industries because I have good insight into them but honestly any advice and recommendation can do nothing but help. Thanks!

body:
AKAM is one of the world's largest CDNs. Amazon has one, too (CloudFront). But FSLY and NET are considered to be the leaders. FSLY, especially, is well positioned to dominate. Here's a good write up on FSLY and their advantages. It's a bit technical.

https://softwarestackinvesting.com/fastly-edge-compute-explained/

author: shacoand2boxes
body:
Akamai Technologies stock is trading higher Thursday after Cowen analyst Colby Synesael raised his rating on the content-delivery network company to Outperform from Market Perform, while upping his target price to $150 from $107.

Synesael is basically making the observation (which I made in an April Tech Trader column) that Akamai shares (ticker: AKAM) have not participated in the huge rally in internet infrastructure plays amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The analyst says there is now a "meaningful disconnect" between Akamai and other security and CDN stocks, despite its larger scale, higher profitability and " still solid growth." He sees Akamai as an "attractive way" to play long-term trends like cloud security and edge computing.

Synesael points out that the stock looks cheap relative to both security plays like Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Fortinet (FTNT) and to other content- delivery networks, such as Cloudflare (NET), Fastly (FSLY), and Limelight Networks (LLNW). He argues that Covid-19 has served as a catalyst to Akamai's security and CDN businesses.

"We believe Covid-19 has resulted in increased demand for both its enterprise and internet security product offerings given the increase in the number of attacks across organizations and the internet," Synesael writes. "We believe Akamai's security business is an underappreciated component of its long- term growth opportunity and that as it becomes a larger portion of total revenue more investors are likely to start valuing it on its [sum of the parts] which we believe will result in a significant re-rating of the stock."

The analyst notes that there have been investor concerns about the company losing market share to peers like Fastly, but asserts that "the growth of competitors is more a function of an expanding opportunity for CDN providers rather than share stealing from Akamai."

Akamai shares were up 7%, at $113.78, in recent trading, while the S&P 500 was up 0.9%. The stock is up about 32% year to date, which is impressive growth -- except when compared with Cloudflare, which has more than doubled, and Fastly, which has more than quadrupled

author: K215215
body: Yes, FAANG are the biggest companies, but look at the market caps for companies like SHOP, CRM, AKAM, OKTA, SQ, PYPL, CRWD, COUP etc. They're not as big as MSFT and FB but their still fucking huge and growing 30-40% a year. These are big companies with much different business models than you're describing

author: haraami_shakaal
body: Keep an eye on AKAM folks. This is the most underrated work from home stock with actually generating profits and gaining more customers , internet traffic. Companies like fastly in the same space have more than quadrupled with no revenue. I know that it is future looking, but look at the customers these both companies have and you will be appalled. Plus akamai has been expanding rapidly in areas outside america, so its very diversified. I am eyeing there earnings.
